questions.question: .................................... like hamburgers.
questions.description: All + noun cannot be the subject of a negative verb. Instead we write ‘not all + noun + affirmative verb’.

questions.question: I have been round ............................ looking for my puppy.
questions.description: The expression ‘all the village’ means every part of the village.

questions.question: Susie spent .................................. at home.
questions.description: The article should go before whole.

questions.question: My dog understands every word I say – he is ............................ human.
questions.description: Almost can mean ‘similar to but not exactly the same’. Nearly is not used with this meaning.

questions.question: I ............................ wish I had accepted the invite.
questions.description: Almost can mean ‘similar to but not exactly the same’. Nearly is not used with this meaning.

questions.question: .............................. nobody came.
questions.description: Nearly cannot be used before negative words.

questions.question: I have just read ............................. Brothers Karamazov.
questions.description: Before proper nouns all of and the whole of are both possible.

questions.question: Students are not ................................. to park here.
questions.description: The verbs allowed and permitted can both be used in passive structures.

questions.question: I wasn’t .............................. to enter the club.
questions.description: Let is not used in the passive.

questions.question: ‘She is kind.’ ‘Her sister is .............................’
questions.description: We do not normally use also in short answers.

questions.question: Please give me some rice ............................
questions.description: Also is not normally used in imperatives.
